technical_concept: Using Strings for basic key-value storage with SET, GET, and SETEX for expiry.

challenge.task: A new person of interest, `user456`, just came online. Mark their status as 'online' but make sure the lead goes cold (expires) in exactly 2 minutes (120 seconds).
challenge.hint: SETEX lets you set a key with an expiry in one command. The syntax is SETEX key seconds value.

dialogue.line: Indecks.
Got a new lead for you, detective. A shadowy figure, `user789`. We need to track them, but only when they're active. We can't waste resources tailing them when they go dark.
So I need a way to put a temporary tag on them. What's the tool?

The simplest tool in the box. A basic key-value pair. You give me a key, like `online:user789`, and a value, like 'active'. My `SET` command handles it. If you need to check the status, you just ask me with `GET online:user789`.
But you said temporary. What if I forget to remove the tag? The lead goes cold, but my board still says they're active. Sloppy work.

That's why you don't use `SET`. You use `SETEX`—SET with Expiry. You give me the key, the number of seconds to keep the lead alive, and the value. For example: `SETEX online:user789 300 "active"`. In 5 minutes (300 seconds), that record vanishes. No loose ends. No sloppy work.
Clean. I like it. Let's put it to the test.
Engineer, incoming transmission. Crew member designation CR-789 has just logged into the main terminal.
I need to track their online status, but only while they're actively connected. Can't waste memory on stale session data.
Understood. We use key-value pairs for efficient tracking. I can store a key like 'session:CR-789' with a value of 'active'. To check their status later, simply query with GET.
But what about when they disconnect? I can't manually purge every session marker.

That's why we use SETEX - SET with EXpiry. Specify the key, duration in seconds, and value. Example: SETEX session:CR-789 300 'active'. After 300 seconds, the data automatically purges. Zero maintenance overhead.
Efficient. I like it. Let's test this auto-cleanup system.
Ready to receive your command, Engineer.

styles.name: shakespearean
styles.title: Of Fleeting Marks and Temporal Tags

dialogue.line: REDIS, a visitor approaches—User456, a most suspicious character! I must mark their presence, yet only whilst they tarry.
Ah, my lord seeks the art of the ephemeral notation! For this, we employ the humble String—a key paired with its value, as lovers in the moonlight.
But what if mine memory fails me? What if I forget to strike their name when they depart? Such negligence would shame mine house!

Fear not! For I possess SETEX—'tis SET with EXpiry most wondrous! Thou givest me the key 'online:user456', the seconds it shall live, and its value. Example: SETEX online:user456 120 'online'. In two minutes' time—120 heartbeats—the record shall vanish like morning dew!
A self-cleaning ledger! 'Tis sorcery most practical!
No sorcery, my lord—merely the passage of time made useful. The data expires as naturally as the setting sun.
Then let us inscribe this temporary mark and watch time claim it back!
Okay team, we need to track user sessions. When someone logs in, we mark them as 'online'. When they log out, we clear the marker. Simple, right?
What if they don't log out properly? Like, what if they just close the browser?
Then we have ghost sessions clogging up the system forever. It's like leaving yogurt in the break room fridge—eventually someone has to clean it up.
That's why I have SETEX. SET with EXpiry. You set a key with a timeout. After those seconds elapse, I automatically delete it. Zero manual cleanup required.
So I just... tell you how long to remember something?
Exactly. SETEX online:user456 120 'online' means: Remember that user456 is online, but only for 120 seconds. After that, forget about them completely.
It's like setting a timer on the microwave, except instead of reheating burrito, you're managing session state.
That's... actually pretty elegant.
I like to think so. Now let's track user456 with a 2-minute expiration and prove this works.
